questions.question_text:
Which three statements about configuring an encrypted trunk between Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server and Cisco Unified Communications
Manager are true? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
correct answer A,C,E
VCS configuration > Zones > Zones

Port 5061
Transport TLS
TLS verify mode On
Authentication trust mode Off

choices.B: A SIP trunk security profile must be configured with Incoming Transport Type set to TCP+UDP.
choices.F: The Cisco Unified Communications Manager zone configured in VCS must have SIP authentication trust mode set to On.
choices.G: The Cisco Unified Communications Manager zone configured in VCS must have TLS verify mode set to Off.
choices.C: The Cisco Unified Communications Manager trunk configuration must have the destination port set to 5061.
choices.A: The root CA of the VCS server certificate must be loaded in Cisco Unified Communications Manager.
choices.E: A SIP trunk security profile must be configured with the X.509 Subject Name from the VCS certificate.
choices.D: A SIP trunk security profile must be configured with Device Security Mode set to TLS.

discussion.content: I think the correct answer is A. The questions ask for a "feature" that it takes affect on the manipulation of calling party. "Calling party transformation pattern" is a setting which you can apply in several places (Transformation, RouteList, RoutePattern etc.)

questions.question_text: Which feature can be used to manipulate the calling party numbers of internal calls, post digit analysis?

Video calls using 384 kbps need to be supported across a gatekeeper-controlled trunk. What value should be entered into the gatekeeper to support this bandwidth? (SourcE. Configuring Cisco Unified Video Advantage)
questions.answer_description:
Incorrect answer : ACD -
Explanation : A 384-kb/s video call may comprise G.711 at 64 kb/s (for audio) plus 320 kb/s (for video). This sum does not include overhead. If the audio codec for a video call is G.729 (at 24 kb/s), the video rate increases to maintain a total bandwidth of 384 kb/s.
Link:
http://www.ciscosystems.com/en/US/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/8_6_1/ccmsys/a08video.ht ml#wp1059726

discussion.content:
The bandwidth that is assumed by the gatekeeper for each call is twice the bandwidth of the audio codec. A G.729 call is configured for 16 kbps, and a G.711 call is configured for 128 kbps. This is not the actual bandwidth seen on the wire, but itâ€™s the standard used when configuring gatekeeper CAC to represent a call. Multiple calls are simply calculated as an even multiple of these numbers, 16 and 128. Therefore, it is critical to
know which codec is being used when configuring gatekeeper CAC.

questions.question_text:
A CUCM Cluster has been setup with one-to-one (1:1) call processing redundancy. What two occurrences will be seen when the primary subscriber fails?
(Choose two.)

choices.C: 40 SIP phones per second will be able to register to the secondary subscriber.
choices.D: 125 SIP phones per second will be able to register to the secondary subscriber.
choices.F: The secondary subscriber will start its CallManager service. BC
choices.B: 125 SCCP phones per second will be able to register to the secondary subscriber.
choices.E: 40 SCCP phones per second will be able to register to the secondary subscriber.
choices.A: The secondary subscriber will start its TFTP service.
